parts.fpdescription: Here you can see how a little ‘Porphyrian tree’ has been added in the inner margin even when there was hardly space
Here you can see how a later reader added large ‘NOTA’ signs as tiemarks, to clear up the puzzle of where to place the gloss.
Here you can see how a first reader went really fancyfull with inventing a new tiemark, and how a later reader drew a line between text and gloss to mark them off a bit more clearly
Here you can see how a little ‘Porphyrian tree’ has been added in the inner margin even when there was hardly space
Here you can see how a later reader added large ‘NOTA’ signs as tiemarks, to clear up the puzzle of where to place the gloss.
Here you can see how a first reader went really fancyfull with inventing a new tiemark, and how a later reader drew a line between text and gloss to mark them off a bit more clearly
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 27 bis r

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 1r. Opening of Aristotle’s Peri Hermeneias (On Interpretation) in the translation of Boethius. You may recognize this page from the teaser of this exhibition. Aristotle’s On Interpretation deals with the relationship between words, reality and logic.
At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’
Introduction (accessus) to the author, Augustine, and an etymology of the word dialectica, with a reference to John Scot Eriugenia.
Opening of De dialectica, with the well-known opening words: “Dialectia est bene disputandi scientia”; “Dialectic is the art of arguing well.
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 46r: opening of Porphyry’s Isagoge, an introduction to the Categories of Aristotle
‘We should not accept this gloss’ - ‘Non est haec glossa a nobis recipienda.’
At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’
Paris, BnF, Lat. 12963, f. 8v (detail). Cassiodorus, Institutiones. Ms. from Corbie, second half of the 10th century.
Paris, BnF, lat. 14614, ff. 117-202 (the opening of the text is missing). Date: 12th century. The manuscript belonged to the library of St. Victor, Paris.
Paris, BnF, lat. 16598: Augustinus’ Dialectica and John of Damascus’ Logica
Note the distinction made between mortal (and rational) man and mortal (and irrational) cows, dogs, etc.
Here, as might befit a book belonging to a theologian, Peter and Paul substitute for Plato and Socrates as examples of the species ‘man’.
Paris, BnF, lat 16611: Porphyrius, predicamenta, periermenias, divisiones, sex principia
Paris, BnF, lat. 16611, f. 7v: Square of opposition
Paris, BnF, lat. 16611, f. 8v: Porphyrian tree

‘<Barbara> [erased], Celarent, Darii, Ferio, Baralipton, Celantes’ Here these names do double-duty; they remind the reader of the mnemonic verse, but they also indicate where the description of each mood can be found in the text.
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 218r: Opening of Analytica Posteriora
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 164v: Opening of Analytica Priora
Portrait of a master teaching a student
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 69r: a column for commentary on the left of the tekst, and two columns on the right. The lower margin is also typically large to house large amounts of notes and comments

A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation.

In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.
Paris, BnF, lat 2788 (ca 1000), f. 49r: Opening page of Aristotle’s Categories
Paris, BnF, lat. 2923 (mid 13th c.), f. 49r: Abelard, Apologia seu fidei confessio ‘Universis’ (1141)
Paris, BnF, lat. 6638, f. 6r: Square of opposition
Substantia, Corpus, Animatum Corpus, Animal, Homo, Socrates
Paris, BnF, lat. 7749, f. 33v: Victorinus’s commentary included a number of summary diagrams. Cicero’s text is added in red in the margins.
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 132v: 'Lady Dialectica' (left) lures in students (right).
A personification of the discipline of grammar (Lady Grammar) is teaching a schoolclass. The pupils in the front row have wax tablets to practice their letters and words.
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 140v: Portrait of Lady Rhetoric
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 151v: Portrait of Lady Astronomy
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 153v: Illustration of 'Lady Music'
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f.133r: The opening of Martianus’ chapter on dialectic, with Remigius' commentary (on the right)
Written nota signs from the original annotating hand (below) and from the later one (above)
A written Nota sign in the original hand, and a drawn head as attention sign in the later hand.
A foot (?) and a hand at the edge of fol. 17v
A hand, leg or arm (?) and face on fol. 37r
BPL 144, f.43r (1) call attention to certain things
A head and peculiar animal on fol. 49v
In manuscripts, marginal notes are used to (1) call attention to certain things
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 62v: Opening with the text of Martianus Capella, De nuptiis
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, ff. 1v-2r: Opening of Boethius' Consolatio Philosophiae
You can see that the material was already damaged when the scribe was copying the commentary into the margins: he/she deals with the damages parchment and the hole in it.
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail): Square of opposition
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail): Square of opposition

In close-up, the dirt and wear and tear on the page are even more visible. We can also see that a later hand wrote the title of the work on the top of the page: ‘Aristotelis liber i peri er[meneias] a boecio comentatus expositusque’ (see green box) (The first book of Aritotle’s Peri hermeneias, commented upon and expounded by Boethius). In the red box you can see the Greek title of Aristotle’s work, Peri Hermeneias. It is written in Greek capitals. A line over the words emphasizes the fact that it is Greek.
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: List of propositions

The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’.

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.
On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection.
An example of numbers (‘ii’), from f. 32v
f. 13r: ‘Retro in libro topicorum iii’: ‘Back in book III of the Topics’
f. 14r: ‘Retro in fine libri tercium topicorum ciceronis’: ‘Back in the end of the third book of Cicero’s Topics’
Here on f. 44v, two sets of rubrics (written in red) indicate that one text has ended and that another will begin on the next page.
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8r: a decorated initial is used for the first word of a new text
Leiden, UB, BPL 84: Furthermore, a new set of quire gatherings starts on f. 17r; from this point to the end of the manuscript quires are numbered with numbers, not letters.

Text in the box: ‘According to Calcidius, entelechy is perfecta aetas, completed lifetime. According to Aristotle, it is interpreted as absolute perfection. Plato, on the other hand, says that entelechy is the anima mundi, the soul of the world.’
f.94r Opening of Priscian's De Constructione with initial of Lady Grammar
f.143r The opening of the Pseudo-Ciceronian Rhetorica ad Herennium
f.166r The opening of Boethius’ translation of Porphyry’s Isagoge

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 29 (878), p. 165: Manuscripts were often ruled with a knife; here we can see on p. 165 that the blade has cut through the parchment while ruling the edge of the text block.

This passage of annotation gives us a clue about the kind of readers Cod. 29 (878) was expected to receive. As the first word, ‘ordo’, suggests, this gloss amounts to a reordering of the first words of Porphyry’s text (‘Cum sit necessarium...’). Glosses of this type helped medieval students make sense of Latin, and suggest that this copy of the Isagoge was prepared for an elementary readership.
Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315 (605), p. 139: representation of Porphyry’s five predicables
The text has been carefully corrected, here ‘ad’ has been corrected to ‘ab’ and ‘actenus’ to ‘hactenus’.
Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary.

Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively.
These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 1r: The opening of Cicero’s De inventione
Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation.
‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ .

The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and  characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text.
These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.
On f. 58v, a glossator adds Augustine’s list of the eight categories of lies (De mendacio, 25).
Karlsruhe, BLB, St.Peter perg. 92, f. 11v: Ramon Llull in discussion
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 6v: Aristotle's army
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 1v: Ramon receives his vision
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 3v: Ramon learns Arabic from his assistant
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 10r: Ramon is attacked by an angry mob. This single image depicts five different scenes.
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 7r
Karlsruhe, BLB, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 5r
Valenciennes, BM, Ms. 404, f. 27r. Manuscript made in Saint Amand in the ninth century.
Valenciennes, BM, Ms. 406, f. 2r: Opening of Cicero's Topica
The other scribe added a note on musical pitches, and two sets of schemes regarding syllogistic propositions.
A line separates the sets of examples of syllogisms.
We know who one of these scribes was – Rather of Verona (890-974) added a copy of a letter at the base of the page.

For example, using a ‘mixed’ syllogism: ‘Whether the knowledge of discussing is useful. If good discussion is useful, the science of discussing well is useful. But good discussion is useful... Therefore dialectic is useful.’
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 31r: example of a very full commentary added in the margin. The book is 307 mm high.

In the second set of schemes lines connect terms of the propositions and conclusion in order to indicate how the argument is constructed. Visualising the argument in this way helps understand why it is valid.
The scheme is evidence of a reader trying to understand the steps made by Dialectic in reaching this conclusion; the scheme illustrates the reader’s thought process!
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 46r: opening of Porphyry’s Isagoge, an introduction to the Categories of Aristotle
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v. At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’.
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v. At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’.

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r (detail): ‘Rara est adeo concordia formae atque pudicitiae’: ‘Beauty rarely coincides with chastity’ (Juvenal, Satires, 10.295) – gloss to De inventione I.XXIV.35, where Cicero notes that a person could be either handsome or ugly.
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r (detail): ‘Rara est adeo concordia formae atque pudicitiae’: ‘Beauty rarely coincides with chastity’ (Juvenal, Satires, 10.295) – gloss to De inventione I.XXIV.35, where Cicero notes that a person could be either handsome or ugly.

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 41v (detail): ‘Facilius est commendare paupertatem quam sustinere’: ‘It is easier to praise poverty than to put up with it’. The quotation is attributed to ‘Seneca’ and paraphrases Seneca the Elder’s Controversiae II.18. The passage glosses the question of appropriate reward for virtuous acts (De inventione, II.XXXIX.115)
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 41v (detail): ‘Facilius est commendare paupertatem quam sustinere’: ‘It is easier to praise poverty than to put up with it’. The quotation is attributed to ‘Seneca’ and paraphrases Seneca the Elder’s Controversiae II.18. The passage glosses the question of appropriate reward for virtuous acts (De inventione, II.XXXIX.115)

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 70r (detail): ‘Nichil est iniquius his qui nusquam putant esse subtilitatem nisi ubi nihil est praeter subtilitatem’: ‘Nothing is more unfair than to think that acuteness is only present when there is nothing present but acuteness’. Quoting again from Seneca the Elder (Controversiae, I.21, trans. Winterbottom, LCL 463, p. 21), the quotation glosses Rhetorica ad Herennium II.XI.16, which concerns the dangers of ambiguous oratory.
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 70r (detail): ‘Nichil est iniquius his qui nusquam putant esse subtilitatem nisi ubi nihil est praeter subtilitatem’: ‘Nothing is more unfair than to think that acuteness is only present when there is nothing present but acuteness’. Quoting again from Seneca the Elder (Controversiae, I.21, trans. Winterbottom, LCL 463, p. 21), the quotation glosses Rhetorica ad Herennium II.XI.16, which concerns the dangers of ambiguous oratory.

parts.foliodescription: West door, Cathedral of Chartres, c. 1150. The throne of wisdom, framed by the liberal arts. The complex iconographical program is believed to have been designed by the scholar Thierry of Chartres, chancellor of the cathedral school from 1141 to c. 1155. Famous twelfth-century scholars such as William of Conches and Gilbert of Poitiers studied in Chartres.
parts.fpdescription: West door, Cathedral of Chartres, c. 1150. The throne of wisdom, framed by the liberal arts. The complex iconographical program is believed to have been designed by the scholar Thierry of Chartres, chancellor of the cathedral school from 1141 to c. 1155. Famous twelfth-century scholars such as William of Conches and Gilbert of Poitiers studied in Chartres.

parts.foliodescription: In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and particular negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’
parts.fpdescription: In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and particular negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’

parts.foliodescription: The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictoriae’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then the proposition ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.’
parts.fpdescription: The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictoriae’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then the proposition ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.’

parts.foliodescription: The placement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.
parts.fpdescription: The placement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.

parts.foliodescription: Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’ (placed at the top of the square), is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition, ‘some men are just’ (placed at the bottom of the square), must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’, must also be true.’
parts.fpdescription: Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’ (placed at the top of the square), is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition, ‘some men are just’ (placed at the bottom of the square), must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’, must also be true.’
